fields.description:
h3. Summary
When opening SourceTree and the repos are not open in tabs, and are stored in folders, they just show the double-arrow circle icon like they are still refreshing. After double clicking to open the repo in a tab the status updates in a few seconds.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not show status changes in left-side repo list if the repo is stored in a folder

fields.description: We have tags with several number parts, e.g. 2.3b1, 2.3b2 etc. But they are not sorted numerically and thus the list looks like 2.3b11, 2.3b12, 2.3b1, 2.3b2, etc
fields.summary: Sort tag list numerically for all parts, e.g. 2.3b12

fields.description: Sometimes it is difficult to see real changes in a sea of whitespace only changes.
fields.summary: Use different colors for white-space only changes in diff tool

fields.description: In a slightly older version of SourceTree there was an "Add / Remove" button directly in the toolbar. I used it a lot as I like to add/remove before I commit to review the changes I'm about to commit properly (sometimes a file is marked as deleted while another file is marked as new when it's the same file that was renamed and edited a little, and add/remove marks it as such). I understand the button was removed to clean the UI, and I appreciate that, but I don't understand why it's not available in the list of buttons that can be added when customizing the toolbar (see the attached screenshot). It would definitely help my workflow if I was able to re-add that button; it's the toolbar button I used the most after Pull and Branch.
fields.summary: Ability to add "Add / Remove" button to toolbar

fields.description: We're 10.8+, sidebar contents should support expansion tooltips to show truncated items.
fields.summary: Expansion tooltips for sidebar content

fields.description:
When click with right mouse button it opens a menu.
Would be helpful to add an item "Open With..." that will enable to choose the application to open with the file.
fields.summary: Add a Menu Item "Open With..." to a right click menu on a file

fields.description:
The "Advanced Options" in Clone Repositories menu is broken.

Steps to reproduce:
1- New Reposiroty -> Select Clone From Url
2- Enter a valid git url that has either submodules or multiple branches.
3- Click on the arrow next to 'advanced options'.
4- Observe that nothing is showing up under the options.
fields.summary: Clone From URL -> Advanced Options not showing up

fields.description:
When I want to perform more actions on a file from the staged / unstaged area, app exposes this functionality through "•••" button. Pressing this button shows a popover with available options / actions (attached) 
Currently that seems to be a custom component and not a standard OS X menu (such as ones that can be accessed through the menu panel at the top of the screen)
Disadvantages of using a custom component is that I can't leverage keyboard navigation (such as arrows up and down) or typing first few letters of the menu item I want to move to (e.g. pressing rapidly keys "S", "H", "O" would jump me to "Show in Finder" item if the component would be a menu)

I'm sure you understand that being a developer tool, Source Tree benefits from allowing fast access to advanced features without leaving the comfort of my keyboard. (Additional comfort can be added by allowing to show the actions popup with a hotkey while a file is selected)
fields.summary: Replace file "more actions" custom popover with a standard OS X menu

fields.description:
In the Branch Graph view (Top right pane). Branch labels with long names are not readable if the window is too narrow as it is cutting the text off (seems to be wrapping) at the slash rather than hide the text at right of the tag box. This text truncation behaviour means it's not possible to see which branch the tag is referring to.

I've attached a screen recording showing the issue.
fields.summary: Long Branch Name Labels are unreadable in Branch Graph Pane

fields.description:
Although I'm using mouse/touchpad very frequently, sometimes (or especially?) on initial repository setups I am noticing every time this little glitch. :)

In the Git's advanced repository settings, the "tab" is not working from "name" into "email". Just think about the not uncommon use case of typing the user name and then typing the email address.

I have attached a screenshot showing the step exactly.
fields.summary: No tab possible in advanced repository options (user details)

fields.description:
When there are changes on an image file (PNG, JPG, PSD) then the Before view always says that there is "No Preview Available" while the After view shows the image correctly.

*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Add an image file into a repo and commit it
# Make changes to the image file and commit it again

Expected result:
The 'Before' view should show the image file before change

Actual result:
The 'Before' view shows 'No preview available'
fields.summary: 'Before' view for image files is broken on the diff preview

fields.description:
Steps to Repro:
1. Switch between branches where you are behind on commits
2. Check out the commit count on the Pull icon. 

Expect Result: Commit count updates when I switch branches to reflect the # of commits I am missing for the branch that I am on. 
Actual Result: Notice the commit count is for the previous branch I am on and it is not updating. 

This is scary sometimes because you could be wanting to add a commit to latest (instead of merging in a feature branch) but you hesitate because you think you are behind.
fields.summary: Pull Icon Count is stale after branch switch

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Some users get a log in error in SourceTree when adding a Bitbucket Cloud account whose password has symbols like / or { 

h3. Environment
SourceTree 2.2.3 for Mac

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Bitbucket account whose password contains a symbol, e.g. { or /
# Open SourceTree
# Go the gear on the top right corner >> Settings
# Click {{Add account...}}
# Give the credentials for the Bitbucket account, leave protocol as HTTPS, click OK


h3. Expected Results
The account gets added in SourceTree

h3. Actual Results
A log in error is caused
fields.summary: Using a Bitbucket password with a symbol causes log in errors for some users

fields.description:
Control-Click->Move... file to new folder Truncates name

After I choose a different folder, the name ReImporter.h shows up us eImporter.h.

Furthermore, I have to quite SourceTree and relaunch to get the eImport.h to show up in the pending changes.

 Note: I just tried a workaround where in the "choose destination" dialog, if i put a space before the name, it moves and renames appropriately.

Note: I just noticed that the change log history is not preserved.  

Note: I just notice a bunch of files left around.

I know this is a poorly written bug but it would appear there are a lot of issues with the Move... command
fields.summary: Control-Click->Move... file to new folder Truncates name

fields.description: As the title says, it would be great to have an option to show the master branch graph on the most left side and all the other created branches sorted by creation date from left to right.
fields.summary: Show master branch graph on the most left side

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a user attempts to make a commit while in the middle of a rebase, a {{Rebase in Progress}} dialog will pop up, with 3 buttons: {{Cancel}}, {{Abort Rebase}}, {{Continue Rebase}}.

Selecting {{Cancel}} aborts the rebase while selecting {{Abort rebase}} cancels the Commit.

h3. Environment
SourceTree for Mac 2.2.3, 2.2.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Initialize a git repo
# Create a file and commit in master branch
# Create branch develop
# Edit file in develop and commit
# Switch to master branch.
# Edit file so that it creates a conflict with the version in develop branch
# Commit in master branch
# Right-click the commit in develop, select {{Rebase...}}
# {{Confirm Rebase}} dialog appears, select {{OK}}
# A new dialog appears, warning of the conflicts. Select {{Close}}
# {{Merge Conflicts}} dialog appears, select OK
# Click {{Commit}} button from the toolbar
# A dialog {{Rebase In Progress}} appears, with buttons {{Abort Rebase}}, {{Cancel}} and {{Continue Rebase}}

h3. Expected Results
Selecting {{Cancel}} should cancel Commit 
Selecting {{Abort Rebase}} should abort the rebase

h3. Actual Results

Selecting {{Cancel}} aborts the rebase
Selecting {{Abort Rebase}} cancels the Commit
fields.summary: 'Rebase in progress' dialog in SourceTree Mac has wrong button-action mapping

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The left side navigation sidebar on Sourcetree has many collapsible sections (Branches, Tags, Remotes) but it is very hard to click those tiny triangles or the "Show"/"Hide" links. Please make the entire row or at least the label be clickable as well
fields.summary: Make the left side navigation sidebar menu on Sourcetree more clickable

fields.summary: Crash for 'Install Command Line Tools'

fields.description: In the SourceTree for Mac app when viewing the list of available Local repositories, the icon for changes that have been committed by the user but not yet pushed (i.e., white with black outline) is exactly the same as those changes that need to be pulled down. Ideally, these icons would be different so the user can check to see if anything needs to be pulled before pushing to avoid the heart-wrenching merge.
fields.summary: New icon for committed changes (not yet pushed)

fields.description:
1.My Project add submodule
2.open submodule project
3.branches, and others menu,all of  slide menu can not right click
fields.summary: submodule can not right click

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When making a commit by clicking the commit button on the toolbar, and not commiting all files in one go, Sourcetree changes to the history view. This forces a user to go to the mouse, perform a couple extra clicks, every time a commit is done
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Add a few new files into a repo. In this case, I added 3 new files into our test repo
2. Click the COMMIT menu icon.
3. Stage one of the added files and commit it

h3. Expected Results
The file status window still stays where it is.o

h3. Actual Results
The history window is shown.
fields.summary: Stay in Commit / File Status window after committing

fields.description:
The option "prune tracking branches no longer present on remote(s)" does not appear to work

Expected behaviour:

* Have a local branch tracking a remote branch
* Fetch the remote status (through the menu item)
* Set the "prune tracking branches no longer present on remote" option to enabled
* The local branches no longer present on the remote are now deleted

Current behaviour:

 * The local branches are not deleted
fields.summary: Prune tracking branches does not work

fields.description:
It's effectively impossible to delete a tag.

Please see this issue:

https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/STSP-4023
fields.summary: Make it possible to delete a Tag

fields.description:
When creating branches with names containing non-ascii characters, e.g. "teståäö", or when they get checked out, the indicator of the current branch disappears from the sidebar, and the current branch's name is not bold. There's no way to see which branch you're on other than using the terminal (since the status bar seems to have gone in this version of Sourcetree).

fields.description:
Unfortunately the commit.template setting in git is ignored if a path relative to the repository root folder is provided. It only seems to work if absolute paths are provided.

For example this will work, the template text is shown in the commit message editor
git config commit.template ~/Projects/demo_project/.gitmessage.txt

But this will only work if I execute 'git commit' from the command line (regardless in which folder I am in the repository), but the template message will not be shown in the commit message editor in SourceTree:
git config commit.template .gitmessage.txt

The file '.gitmessage.txt' is in the repositories root folder.
Is there any chance to fix this?

Hey! My repos are a little nested. I navigated to my home directory and was hoping to burrow down to find the one I wanted but when I tried to open the subdirectory (which itself contains directories that contain repos) I was told that the parent isn't a valid Git or Mercurial repository. Clearly, I know this. :)

fields.description:
When cloning a repo from a service with an integration (eg Bitbucket or GitHub), it would be nice if SourceTree would automatically add an 'upstream' (perhaps configurable?) remote with the parent repo.  For repos where the ancestry tree is larger than 1, it would be nice if all ancestor repos were added as remotes, with each remote being named after the user owning that particular repo.

Examples:

User 'foo's repo 'bar' is a fork of user 'baz's repo of the same name.  No grandparent repo exists.  Remotes:
origin: git@bitbucket.org:foo/bar.git
upstream: git@bitbucket.org:baz/bar.git

User 'foo's repo 'bar' is a fork of user 'baz's repo of the same name, which is a fork of user 'quux's repo also of the same name.  Remotes:
origin: git@bitbucket.org:foo/bar.git
baz: git@bitbucket.org:baz/bar.git
quux: git@bitbucket.org:quux/bar.git

Of note, though, is that users can usually rename their repositories even if they're a fork, so you cannot rely on the parent repo's name matching up.
fields.summary: Include parent repository(/ies?) as remotes when cloning forks from services with integrations

fields.description: The toolbar is a handy place for many functions, like commit, pull, push, fetch, branch, merge and reset. This request is to add "clean" and it's various options to the toolbar.
fields.summary: Add a "Git Clean" button to the tool bar.

fields.description: There appears to be no way to request a directory diff. Most tools can do individual file comparisons, or a whole directory at a time. Tower has a nice feature where you can compare multiple files at once using, for example, Araxis’s directory comparison feature rather than a whole lot of individual files. In reviewing big pull requests, this is quite nice.
fields.summary: Add support for directory diff

fields.description: If I fetch from remote, and there are 3 commits ahead of me on the current branch, if I right-click on the last commit and reset to that commit, the toolbar will continue to show that there's 3 commits to pull. Hitting "Fetch" again will clear the counts, but this should be automatically recalculated when a reset is performed.

Cheers

fields.description:
*STORY*
As a developer working on a project with multiple git repos, I would like a way to manage those repos in a single window so that I don't have to constantly move multiple windows around my screen.

Would it be possible to combine or dock repo windows together. The project I'm working is made of 4 git repos. So I have 4 windows open at once and have to keep jumping to the next one. It works but just feels awkward. Seems like there should be an easier way.

Thanks,

fields.description:
Could we get back Sourcetree UI as of 1.8 on OSX

Update after discussint with Rahul:

Using Sourcetree on Mac for a while, I am still using Version 1.8. Main reason is that from 1.9 onward the UI is getting worse and worse. Today I gabe 2.23 a try and find my self pretty disappointed.

1. We no longer have the column view as it is well known by mac users (Rahul: Will have a look if we can bring it back).
2. There are too many horizontal lines as separators where we had alternate colors before. These lines are pretty distractive and take much space. Could it be changed by peferences? (Rahul: likely not be changed, was a user request.)
3. the workspace perspectives (File Status | History | Search) are no longer available in the toolbar (Rahul: will not be changed; was a user request)
4. the toolbar icons look ugly and are hard to recognize; maybe if you increase the contrast.
5. there are useless checkboxes in the file view. In particular the checkboxes act as buttons. If user kiicks on checkbox, it should not move the item to another pane. (Rahul: will investigate this. either make checboxes which really perform a selection or make buttons which then immedately move.)

...

The attached screenshots make the issues evident.

It reminds of the Words by Melanie Safka "what have they done to my tool, ma" :-)
fields.summary: Could we get back Sourcetree UI as of 1.8

fields.description:
After the 2.2 update, I found the inconsistent behavior where Source Tree will always successfully delete remote branch *when the Force Delete is unchecked* regardless if the selected remote branch is merged or not.

Expected Behavior:

When trying to delete a remote branch that is not yet merged, Source Tree should fail the deletion if Force Delete is not checked.
fields.summary: Force Delete on remote branch will succeed even if the branch is not merged yet

fields.description: !screenshot.png|thumbnail!

fields.description: Going through SourceTree's license agreement and login dialog the first time is painful enough. Then when we're ready to commit code and do serious work, we get a notice that there's an update. Fine, but when the update is installed, let us get right back to work without presenting the license agreement and login dialog again.

fields.description:
It seems that as of version 2.2 a new set of UI icons have been created for SourceTree for Mac.

Please consider improving the new UI icon set both in the toolbar and in the sidebar as well. The new line icons virtually merge into the void on a 2560x1440 resolution screen.

When you open a Finder window and look at the icons in the sidebar, you can see that there is good contrast between the icons and the background. In addition, the icons in the Finder window are not line icons.

Due to their line weight and their color, the new line icons in SourceTree are hard to see and (especially on the sidebar) gives the illusion as if they were inactive (aka grayed out). But icons on the sidebar that are active have the same light gray color as well which makes it hard to distinguish. Also, there's enough space on the toolbar to make the icons bigger.

Personally I am not fan of the new UI icon set AT ALL. I have no understanding of why you guys had to remove a perfectly fine and nice looking icon set and replace it with a mediocre one.
fields.summary: Please improve the new UI icons

fields.description:

Hide Remote Branches doesn't give me enough detail.
Show Remote Branches shows me everybody on my team's personal branches, which I am not interested in and creates clutter in the graph.

I would like an option that shows remote branches but only those that I am tracking.

fields.description:
As per Dmitri Zaitsev's suggestion, I'm reposting a issue that was erroneously marked as minor so as to bring it to the developer team's attention. The original issue is https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1286

The default font in the actual interface of SourceTree (not the diff view) has very small font. Despite having 20/20 vision, I find it quite difficult to work with, especially on high-res displays. I've searched through the preferences but could not find a way to increase the size of the GUI font.
Please allow changing the font-size and family to any of the system's available fonts. Thanks.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Sourcetree crashes when trying to open Mercurial repos
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open SourceTree
# Open a Mercurial repo

h3. Expected Results
Sourcetree opens up and show the repo

h3. Actual Results
Crash
The exception is thrown in the crash log file attached.

h3. Notes
# Running {{hg verify}} on the repo doesn't seem to have any errors on the repo
# Launches the repo on Sourcetree from the terminal still crashes the app

h3.Workaround
No workaround as for now

fields.description:
When opening a repository window, the sidebar item "File status" is selected and highlighted in blue. Selecting another item, such as "History" removes the blue highlighting from "File status", but leaves its text white, and does not mark "History" in any way.

Something similar happens in the file lists ("Unstaged files" and "Staged files"): the item selected automatically is highlighted with a gray background, but selecting another item displays the differences in the diff window, but does not mark the file in any way. It is thus almost impossible to tell which file is being compared in the diff window.
fields.summary: File status and history sidebar entry clicking is unpredictable

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1. Select commit
2. Select file in left bottom pane
3. Call context menu
4. Select "log selected"
5. You will get a blank window while items are loading.  If you have many changes to the specific file chosen then it can take up to a minute to load, and it seems like ST might have locked.  However, it will eventually load.

If a spinner bar, or loading dialogue was added, it would be a great improvement.
fields.summary: Add loading spinner or dialogue to the file log window for files/items that are still loading.

fields.description:
The monotone button icons are hard to see and to determine what they do. And there are a number buttons missing even though there is still space available for them; e.g., Reset, Merge, etc.

Removing buttons from the menu bar and forcing the user to add them back is NOT and aid to the user. Rearranging the buttons on the button bar forcing the user to re-orient him/her self is NOT an aid to the user.

Also, would be nice if we would have coloured icons or a coloured theme.

fields.description: A previous update restored the icons to the localizable and recognizable ones we are used to (+, - and ...). However, the rename/move icon is still a large "R". fields.description:

Gitlab Web Interface seems to be able to do this. Would be great if we can have this in SourceTree too.

There have been a few topics on this over the years, but all from about 3 years ago.
Can we have an update on this feature?

Related:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/161107/word-by-word-diff-for-sourcetree
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/241069/intraline-diffs-with-sourcetree

fields.description: Positioning of PUSH-PULL-FETCH icons are not good for big screens. I work on iMac(21.5-inch, Mid 2011). Normally my eyes are on change history block in sourceTree. fields.description:
This is the OSX version of SRCTREEWIN-4687.

We have a smudge/clean filter called "git bin" (https://github.com/seeq12/git-bin) that we use to deal with large files. (git-lfs didn't exist until recently or we probably would have used that.)

As of my upgrade in December, SourceTree's invocation of git no longer finds the "git bin" filter. Invoking "git bin" works fine from the OSX command line. There is a video attached to the issue referenced above that walks through the issue. But to be clear, the same behavior is experience on the Mac (which is this bug).

This has prevented me from using SourceTree. I have use the git CLI to do anything that involves pushing/pulling.
fields.summary: SourceTree git filter support broken

fields.description:
Long commit messages scroll off of the available dialogue windows instead of being truncated to fit.

TO reproduce:
1. Create repository
2. Make any changes 
3. Commit with long message (any long message, 'lorem ipsum ...' will be good). It can be singl eline message or multiline, no matter.
4. Make other changes and commit it with any message.
5. Select first commit, open context menu and call "Reset master to this commit"
6. You will see window, that appears on top of program (see screenshot). It may be so wide, wider than your screen.
fields.summary: Long commit messages are not truncated within dialog screen

fields.description:
h3. the problem
I just got the latest SourceTree ({{2.2.2}} via _brew cask_) and started it up.

It got to the splash screen asking me to agree to the new customer agreement, and remembered that my old version was still running.  So I figured I would quit the new and the old, then restart the new (_just in case_ there could be any conflicts with both running).

Well, it won't let me quit (without accepting the new customer agreement).

h3. more detail / background
(⌘Q does nothing, and ⌘W is the same as clicking the close-box {{X}}.  This is fine by me, and is correctly reflected in the File menu, too.)

When I try to close the window, it gives a mostly helpful dialog, like so:
!exit clicked, agree=false.png!

While the options are readily decodable from the context, _*neither of the options actually quits*_.  Both just dismiss the dialog box.

If I check the "I agree" option, the result is slightly different:
!exit clicked, agree=true.png!

In this case, the two options work almost﻿^†^ as expected.

{panel}
^†^ It actually crashes instead, allowing me to send some comments to Apple before picking between {{OK}} and {{Reopen}}.
{panel}

h3. expected
A user shouldn't have to agree to anything in particular to _exit_ the Setup Assistant.

What if I really couldn't abide by the new agreement?  That makes Force Quit just about the only honest option for me.  (now I'm really curious what would happen if I attempted to restart my computer, or even just log out)
fields.summary: Cannot exit without accepting new Atlassian Customer Agreement
